author: admin
title: A face of the club subject to very big sanctions
text: Published on 09/26/2024 at 6:31 p.m. 2 minutes of reading Passionate about sport and more particularly football since my early childhood. Read more Olympique de [Marseille](/tag/Marseille) won an epic Olympico against Olympique Lyonnais last weekend (3-2), a success snatched in a tense context and with one player less for almost the entire match. This match, marked by numerous refereeing decisions, sparked strong reactions, notably those from Medhi Benatia, the club’s sports advisor. The former Moroccan international did not hide his dissatisfaction with Benoît Bastien’s refereeing, expressing his irritation in a particularly vehement manner. Benatia in serious danger Now, this attitude could cost him dearly. According to information from ProvenceBenatia was summoned by the disciplinary committee of the Professional Football League (LFP) to answer for his comments deemed inappropriate. The commission is due to meet this week to rule on the case of the former Juventus defender. The main risk for him? A four-match suspensiona sanction which corresponds to the scales applied for “hurtful comments outside of a meeting”. However, the LFP has a certain latitude to adjust the sanction according to the seriousness of the alleged acts. Indeed, if his words are considered particularly inappropriate, the suspension could be revised upwards. Conversely, a more nuanced statement or mitigating circumstances could lead to a reduction in the sentence. In a context where managing emotion after a tense match can be difficult, the committee will have to weigh its decisions carefully. For Olympique de Marseille, this potential sanction represents a hard blow. Medhi Benatia plays an essential role within the Marseille organization, bringing his experience and his vision of football. His prolonged absence could complicate sporting coordination within the club, especially at a time when OM needs stability. It remains to be seen whether the disciplinary committee will show leniency or whether it will be necessary to do without its services for several weeks. Whatever the case, this affair illustrates once again the extent to which pressure can mount around Olympique de Marseille, a club often at the heart of debates and controversies, especially when it comes to clashes at high voltage like the Olympico.

author: Marguerite de Lasa
title: Catholic Church in Venezuela renews criticism of the Chavista government - Catholic news – La Croix International
text: Catholic Church in Venezuela renews criticism of the Chavista government Interview: International pressure continues to increase on President Nicolás Maduro following his highly contested reelection. The Catholic Church issued statements July 30 and 31 calling for verification of the results. This marks a return to its critical stance against the Chavista regime, which had softened in recent years, explains political scientist Guillermo Tell Aveledo Coll, a professor at the Metropolitan University of Caracas. La Croix: The bishops of Venezuela published statements on July 30 and 31 requesting the detailed results of the July 28 presidential election, in which Nicolás Maduro claimed victory. What is the current position of the Venezuelan Catholic Church amid this political crisis? Guillermo Tell Aveledo Coll: We are experiencing a very delicate moment in Venezuela. Following the election, the government released results showing Nicolás Maduro as the winner, which has generated strong rejection and many doubts. The bishops' conference reacted by issuing a statement. In it, they returned to their traditional criticism of the government, with a tone that was much harsher compared to the more moderate statements in recent years. The bishops are calling for the verification of detailed results. While they condemn the violence of the protests, they disapprove of the way authorities have responded to the demonstrators. Two authoritative figures in the church, Cardinals Baltazar Porras and Diego Padron, also sent a letter to the bishops' conference with severe reproaches toward the government. Do these declarations indicate a shift in the church's stance toward Nicolás Maduro's government? Relations between the [bishops' conference](https://international.la-croix.com/world/catholic-bishops-urge-participation-in-crucial-venezuelan-election) and the state have seen a sort of thaw in recent years. After Hugo Chavez came to power in 1999, the relationship was marked by great mutual hostility. Chavismo equated the church hierarchy with the old social and economic elites of representative democracy. As Chavismo presented itself as a critique of this system, the church became one of its natural enemies. Chavez, for instance, used symbols of popular religiosity to distinguish the religion of the people from that of the elites he opposed. In turn, the church adopted a very critical stance against Chavismo, defending democracy in line with the church's social doctrine and for ideological reasons. When Chavismo declared itself socialist, even Marxist, the church responded with traditional anti-communist rhetoric. Did any part of the Church support Hugo Chavez? Initially, yes. Several voices within the church supported him, particularly in Jesuit circles. However, as Chavismo became more authoritarian, these voices grew critical and eventually supported political change. Figures like Bishop Mario Moronta of San Cristóbal, who was the most conciliatory with Chavismo within the hierarchy, eventually criticized the regime's authoritarian turn. Similarly, Father Arturo Sosa, the Superior General of the [Jesuits](https://international.la-croix.com/news/world/venezuelan-jesuits-issue-warning/5324) and a Venezuelan historian and political scientist, initially understood the causes behind Chavismo but gradually became more critical. Has this mutual hostility between the church and the regime softened in recent years? Yes, Nicolás Maduro's government sought to align with conservative sectors. For about five years, just before the pandemic, it toned down its most radical rhetoric and tried to improve relations with the church, including by approving bishop appointments. In Venezuela, church-state relations are governed by a concordat, requiring state approval for church appointments. During the early Chavismo years, these approvals were withheld. Further reading: [In Colombia, the impossible vote for Venezuelan exiles](https://international.la-croix.com/world/in-colombia-the-impossible-vote-for-venezuelan-exiles) The warming of relations was also evident with the beatification of Dr. José Gregorio Hernandez (1864-1919), a popular Catholic figure in Venezuela known for aiding the poor and attributed with many miracles. His beatification had stalled, possibly due to the syncretic devotion he inspired. The government lobbied for his beatification, which was declared in 2021. Additionally, while Maduro courted evangelical churches with financial benefits, he has also supported Catholic parishes to win over local priests. Why did the church soften its criticisms against the government in the same period? The church maintained its general social and political criticisms but refrained from explicitly condemning the government. It called for conciliation and strengthened its role as a mediator, influenced by the context of repression and societal control by the regime. In some ways, Chavismo's authoritarianism worked: the opposition couldn't propose a real alternative, leading sectors of society, like the traditional bourgeoisie, to adopt a cautious stance. The church also followed this trend. However, with recent elections, the church has resumed a critical stance. Does the church's voice still hold weight in Venezuela? Yes, Catholics are the majority in Venezuela. Traditionally moderate, the church rarely addresses issues of sexual morality, gender, or spiritual matters, focusing instead on inequality and poverty. Without direct power, the church holds significant moral authority, and its statements are always anticipated. Cardinal Baltazar Porras, for instance, the Archbishop Emeritus of Caracas and a member of the National Academy of History of Venezuela, is a prominent intellectual figure. Though not a conservative, he has consistently criticized Maduro's regime. It is also important to note that religious freedom is not threatened in Venezuela.

organizations.name: catholic news – la croix international catholic church

author: Redaktion ONETZ
title: Lobkowitz-Realschule feiert 75-Jähriges mit Jubiläumskonzert in Neustadt
text:
Am Dienstagabend hatte die Lobkowitz-Realschule zu einem Jubiläumskonzert anlässlich ihres 75-jährigen Bestehens eingeladen. In der voll besetzten Stadthalle Neustadt präsentierten die Schülerinnen und Schüler unter dem Motto „Hits der 50er Jahre bis heute“ ein abwechslungsreiches Programm, das durch die Jahrzehnte seit dem Bestehen der Schule führte. Mit kleinen Anekdoten, Funfacts und witzigen Quizfragen, die nach Angaben der Lobkowitz-Realschule so manchen Zuschauer zum Schwitzen brachten, führten die Moderatorinnen Sara Roderer, Lilia Schuchart und Luna Nunez Hübner durch das Programm.
Der Abend hatte mit einem mitreißenden Tanz-Rock'n'Roll-Medley begonnen, das die Tänzerinnen des Wahlfaches Tanz unter der Leitung von Katharina Gallitzendorfer darboten. Es folgten bekannte Klassiker der 50er Jahre wie „Day-O" (Banana Boat Song) von Harry Belafonte, gesungen von der Klasse 5E unter der Leitung von Katharina Endres, sowie „Lollipop“ der Chordettes, vorgetragen vom Schulchor.
Von ABBA bis Kiss
Die Bandklasse 5d sorgte mit „Sweets for my Sweet“ zuerst musikalisch und dann mit einem echten Süßigkeitenregen für eine Überraschung. Bevor die Big Band unter der Leitung von Petra Lindner wegen der großen Anzahl an Mitwirkenden (ehemalige Schüler, ehemalige und aktuelle Lehrkräfte) in beeindruckender Größe die Bühne betrat und „Summer Nights“ aus „Grease“ sowie „I love Rock 'n' Roll“ von Kiss in einer rockigen Form präsentierte, zeigte der von Lena Rötzer geleitete Chor mit dem ABBA-Stück „Dancing Queen“, wie intensiv die Probenarbeit vorher gewesen sein musste. Ein weiteres Highlight war das hervorragende Violinspiel von Sarah Winkler und ihrer Lehrkraft Maike Erchinger.
Sowohl die Big Band als auch der Chor wurden von den weiteren Musiklehrerinnen und Musiklehrern, Bernhard Schmidhuber (Klavier), Stefan Reiger (Bass und verantwortlich für die Technik), Katharina Endres (Gesang), Julia Schwarzmeier-Moises (Querflöte) sowie Tobias Neubert (Schlagzeug) unterstützt, so dass sich "ein wunderbares Zusammenspiel aller Lehrkräfte mit den Schülerinnen und Schülern ergab", wie die Schule mitteilt. Besonders beeindruckend und ebenfalls in das Jahrzehnt der 70er passend sei die Darbietung von Elias Sertl am Klavier gewesen, "der mit einem ABBA-Medley begeisterte".
Witziger "Musikwettkampf"
Zur Einstimmung auf die 80er Jahre erklangen Michael Jacksons „Billie Jean“ sowie „I love Rock 'n' Roll“, wieder gespielt von der imposanten Big Band. Ein weiteres Highlight bot die Klasse 6D unter Leitung von Stefan Reiger, die sich mit einem gespielten Streit herumschlug, ob wohl Volksmusik oder doch eher AC/DC die bessere Musik sei. Heraus kam, wie es in der Mitteilung weiter heißt, ein witziger „Musikwettkampf“ zwischen Felix Meier an der Steirischen Harmonika und Ben Skutella an der E-Gitarre, "der in einer tollen Performance der ganzen Klasse zu Songs von AC/DC mündete".
Da die Lobkowitz-Realschule eine Talentgruppe Musik im Angebot hat, entstammten aus diesem für Schülerinnen und Schüler freiwilligen Zusatzzweig die nächsten Beiträge von Andreas Feige am Schlagzeug, der mit „I want it all“ von Queen das Ende der 80er Jahre einläutete, und der Gesangsklasse der 8. Klasse (Einstudierung: Annika Fischer). "Hier gab es musikalisch ein Medley aus Backstreet Boys und den Spice Girls aus den 90er Jahren auf die Ohren", so die Realschule. Gefühlvoll und sehr sauber rundeten die Klassen 5A, 5B und 5C dieses Jahrzehnt mit „If you believe in love tonight“ von Sasha ab.
Stomp-Performance ausgedacht
Danach fand sich das Publikum im Hier und Jetzt mit Hits der vergangenen 25 Jahre wieder, wie „Unstoppable“ von Sia, bei dem Hannah Bühler am Klavier und Leonie Siebert am Schlagzeug perfekt harmonierten, gefolgt von „Einmal um die Welt“ und „Applaus Applaus“ der Bandklasse 6A. Als besondere Einlage hatte sich die 6E selbst eine Stomp-Performance mit verschiedenen Alltagsgegenständen ausgedacht und einstudiert.
Zum großen Finale trat der Projektchor mit vielen ehemaligen Schülerinnen und Schülern sowie aktuellen und früheren Lehrkräften auf. „Unwritten“ von Natasha Bedingfield erzeugte nach Angaben der Schule "bei den Zuhörern Gänsehaut und tosenden Applaus". Schulleiterin Irene Sebald dankte zum Abschluss den zahlreichen Mitwirkenden, bevor der größte Auftritt des Abends folgte: Ein Zusammenschluss von Projektchor und Projekt-Big-Band für das Lied „75 Jahre, die Lobkos“, eine umgedichtete Version des Flippers-Hits „40 Jahre die Flippers“. Unter langanhaltendem Applaus verabschiedeten sich die jungen Akteurinnen und Akteure sowie die ehemaligen Lobkos von ihrem Publikum.

author: DrMagical Contributor
title: Clicking Smarthub 2 since migration to full fibre
text:
Migrated to full fibre, engineer fitted it yesterday. Same BT Smarthub 2 that was fine until yesterday. Now it clicks all the time every 2-3 seconds. Quiet click but still annoying. Not overheating.
Any ideas?
Yes - just tried, tick, tick, tick.....!

author: @bienenschoolnu
title: Alumni Spotlight: Thomas Mesa | Northwestern Bienen School of Music
text: Cuban-American cellist Thomas Mesa ‘14 MMus has won the $50,000 First Prize in the 2016 Sphinx Competition, the Astral Artists 2017 National Auditions, and the Alhambra Orchestra Concerto Competition. He has appeared as soloist with orchestras in the United States and Mexico, including the Los Angeles Philharmonic, Santa Barbara Symphony, Southwest Florida Symphony Orchestra, and the Cleveland Orchestra. As a recording artist, Mesa was featured on the Grammy-nominated album Bonhoeffer with The Crossing choir, led by Donald Nally. Mesa has also appeared with The Crossing as soloist at the Metropolitan Museum of Art in NYC, Longwood Gardens, The Winter Garden and the Theological Seminary in New York City. What made you choose the Bienen School of Music? I didn’t apply to any other graduate programs because I knew that being in Hans Jensen’s cello studio was the way forward for me. He creates a very competitive yet supportive atmosphere for cellists to reach their full potential if they’re willing to dive in and trust the process. Which professors influenced you most during your time at the Bienen School of Music? There’s no question that [Hans Jensen](https://music.northwestern.edu/faculty/profile/hans-jorgen-jensen) was the most influential. He fundamentally changed how I spent time in a practice room, helped me with the mental game of performing and practicing, and created the structured environment that I needed to demystify the instrument. I think about these qualities in his teaching every day and I’m constantly trying to hone them. Additionally, a very influential person in my life has been [Donald Nally](https://music.northwestern.edu/faculty/profile/donald-nally). We met when he needed a cellist to play with BCE (Bienen Contemporary/Early Vocal Ensemble) my first year at Northwestern. We’ve grown close over the years and have worked together on multiple performances and recordings with The Crossing choir. I am always inspired to be a more thoughtful and courageous artist around him; he has shown the world what it’s like to carve a path with your ideas. The performances that I’ve been a part of with him leading The Crossing have been some of the most meaningful and impactful of my career. Tell us about a particular experience that impacted you during your time at the Bienen School of Music. This is a very difficult question because the amount of growth that I experienced at Northwestern is incalculable. The first thing that comes to mind is the general experience in Hans Jensen’s cello studio which was all-consuming. It really pushed my technical and artistic limits beyond my own perception of their limits. I carry those experiences with me every day. I suppose it’s not a specific experience but every single lesson, studio class, and performance where I received feedback from Hans and peers in the studio were certainly the most impactful in a broader sense. What lessons did you learn at Bienen that have continued to resonate with you in your career? I learned that no one is going to do the work for you and there are no excuses. I also learned that your limits as an artist are merely a product of your mindset and perception, and it’s something you can change. Top three of your Desert Island Discs (any genre) Chris Stapleton - Traveller Jacqueline du Pre’s album of concerti Mumford and Sons - Babel Video Mesa performs Lydia Jane Pugh's Carolina's Jig.

author: Patrick
title: Four Ways to Participate in National Bird Feeding Month | Morning Ag Clips
text: AUBURN UNIVERSITY, Ala.—February is among one of the most important months for feeding birds in Alabama, as backyard songbirds have limited access to their favorite foods during the winter. Grab a camera and join the Alabama Cooperative Extension System outdoors to participate in the Great Backyard Bird Count. Alabama Extension is hosting an online photo contest Feb. 16-19. Submit photos taken with a cell phone or camera beginning Friday, Feb. 16. Watch the [Alabama Extension Facebook page](https://www.facebook.com/AlabamaExtension) for more details. Alabama Extension Urban Regional Agent [Roosevelt Robinson](https://ssl.acesag.auburn.edu/directory-new/u/Roosevelt-Robinson-pgkOM7uP/) said February is [National Bird Feeding Month](https://www.aces.edu/blog/topics/lawn-garden-urban/february-is-national-bird-feeding-month/). “Whether you are an old hand or a rookie, this month is the ideal time for bird feeders, watchers and anyone else in the spirit to extend a hand to help these avian friends,” Robinson said. Feed the Birds National bird feeding month was established in 1994 to encourage individuals to supplement wild birds’ natural diet during the winter months. Urban Regional Agent [Allyson Shabel](https://ssl.acesag.auburn.edu/directory-new/u/Allyson-Shabel-set78UA0/) said putting out backyard feeders is a great way to help birds during the winter. “Buying a feeder — if you don’t have one — and keeping it full can attract new birds to your landscape,” Shabel said. “It is important to note that birds may prefer some feeders over others, depending on the food type.” [A Beginner’s Guide to Backyard Bird Feeding](https://blog.nwf.org/2011/05/a-beginners-guide-to-backyard-bird-feeding/) from the National Wildlife Federation includes other helpful tips. Identifying Backyard Birds There are several factors to take into account when watching birds in the backyard and beyond. “Birdwatching can begin in the backyard and eventually move to more interesting or challenging places like wooded lots, open pasture lands and even popular birding destinations like Dauphin Island,” said [Lynn Dickinson](https://ssl.acesag.auburn.edu/directory-new/u/Lynn-Dickinson-gyIFsC1G/), a regional forestry and natural resources agent. Dickinson said the most difficult part of birding is determining which species of bird the birder is observing. “The first thing to look at is the size and shape of the bird,” Dickinson said. Other characteristics to note include: - Color pattern - Behavior - Habitat Learn more about identifying backyard birds in Dickinson’s Extension Brief titled [Keys to Successful Bird Identification](https://www.aces.edu/blog/topics/forestry-wildlife/keys-to-successful-bird-identification/). If You Build It, They Will Come Bluebirds, robins, chickadees, titmice, wrens and purple martins are able to easily adapt to using bird houses. Location makes no difference to these species as long as there is a small patch of suitable habitat. Learn how to construct a nest box in the Alabama Extension publication, [Bird Houses for Songbirds.](https://www.aces.edu/blog/topics/forestry-wildlife/bird-houses-for-songbirds/) The Great Backyard Bird Count Each year between Feb. 16-19, people come together to observe, count, celebrate and educate themselves about birds through the [Great Backyard Bird Count.](https://www.aces.edu/blog/topics/natural-resources-urban/join-the-great-backyard-bird-count/) [Karnita Garner](https://ssl.acesag.auburn.edu/directory-new/u/Karnita-Golson-Garner-a2pBVOOV/), an urban forestry, wildlife and natural resources Extension specialist, said this popular citizen science project helps researchers learn more about fluctuations in bird populations. “The Great Backyard Bird Count also helps scientists monitor changes in bird migration and distribution patterns,” Garner said. “Scientists use this information to protect birds, their habitat and the environment.” Garner said by participating, birdwatchers can increase their environmental stewardship while helping researchers learn more about these splendid creatures. Alabama Extension is supporting senior citizens as they seek to participate in the Great Backyard Bird Count in Alabama through the [Virginia Caples Lifelong Learning Institute](https://www.aces.edu/blog/topics/home-family-urban/virginia-caples-lifelong-learning-institute/). Visit the official Backyard Bird Count webpage to register at [www.birdcount.org](http://www.birdcount.org/). More Information Watch an [Eco-Friendly Friday webinar](https://www.facebook.com/AlabamaExtensionAAMU/videos/332276192490052) where the Alabama Wildlife Federation focused on backyard birding and participation in the upcoming Great Backyard Bird Count. –Katie Nichols, Alabama Cooperative Extension

author: Kevin Glenton
title: Flood warning and alerts in North and East Yorkshire | York Press
text: FLOOD warnings and alerts have been issued or updated for parts of North Yorkshire. In Malton, the Environment Agency has issued one flood alert – meaning flooding is possible – at 7.01am this morning (Friday, December 29) for the Upper River Derwent. Two flood warnings – meaning ‘act now, flooding expected’ were removed by the agency in the River Rye and River Seven catchments influencing Malton. A flood warning was issued at 6.53am by the agency on the River Derwent at Buttercrambe Mill, near Stamford Bridge. The Environment Agency said: “River levels are rising on the River Derwent due to Storm Gerrit. “Flooding is forecast to affect locations near the River Derwent, with low-lying land expected to be most affected, particularly around Buttercrambe Mill at Buttercrambe Bridge. “Further rainfall is forecast for the coming days. “Consider putting your flood plan into action.” In Stamford Bridge itself, [flood alerts issued by the Environment Agency yesterday](http://FLOOD%20warnings%20and%20alerts%20have%20been%20issued%20for%20parts%20of%20North%20Yorkshire.%20In%20Malton,%20the%20Environment%20Agency%20has%20issued%20one%20flood%20alert%20at%207.01am%20this%20morning%20(Friday,%20December%2029)%20%E2%80%93%20meaning%20flooding%20is%20possible%20%E2%80%93%20for%20the%20Upper%20River%20Derwent.%20Two%20flood%20warnings%20%E2%80%93%20meaning%20%E2%80%98act%20now,%20flooding%20expected%E2%80%99%20were%20removed%20by%20the%20agency%20in%20the%20River%20Rye%20and%20River%20Seven%20catchments%20influencing%20Malton.%20A%20flood%20warning%20was%20issued%20at%206.53am%20by%20the%20agency%20on%20the%20River%20Derwent%20at%20Buttercrambe%20Mill,%20near%20Stamford%20Bridge.%20The%20Environment%20Agency%20said:%20%E2%80%9CRiver%20levels%20are%20rising%20on%20the%20River%20Derwent%20due%20to%20Storm%20Gerrit.%20%20%E2%80%9CFlooding%20is%20forecast%20to%20affect%20locations%20near%20the%20River%20Derwent,%20with%20low-lying%20land%20expected%20to%20be%20most%20affected,%20particularly%20around%20Buttercrambe%20Mill%20at%20Buttercrambe%20Bridge.%20%E2%80%9CFurther%20rainfall%20is%20forecast%20for%20the%20coming%20days.%20%20%E2%80%9CConsider%20putting%20your%20flood%20plan%20into%20action.%E2%80%9D%20In%20Stamford%20Bridge%20itself,%20flood%20alerts%20issued%20by%20the%20Environment%20Agency%20yesterday%20morning%20remain%20in%20place%20and%20have%20been%20updated.%20Areas%20with%20flood%20warnings%20and%20flood%20alerts%20The%20flood%20warning%20is%20for%20the%20River%20Derwent%20at%20Buttercrambe%20Mill%20and%20areas%20influenced%20by%20rising%20river%20levels:%20%E2%80%A2%09River%20Derwent%20at%20Buttercrambe%20Mill%20%E2%80%93%20Buttercrambe%20Mill%20at%20Buttercrambe%20Bridge%20The%20two%20flood%20alerts%20are%20for%20the%20following%20stretches%20of%20the%20River%20Derwent%20and%20areas%20influenced%20by%20rising%20river%20levels:%20%E2%80%A2%09Lower%20River%20Derwent%20%E2%80%93%20local%20roads%20and%20low-lying%20land%20around%20Stamford%20Bridge,%20Pocklington,%20Wressle,%20Wilberfoss%20and%20Elvington.%20%E2%80%A2%09Upper%20River%20Derwent%20%E2%80%93%20the%20Upper%20Derwent%20and%20Scarborough%20areas,%20including%20land%20around%20The%20Sea%20Cut%20at%20Scalby,%20Throxenby%20Beck,%20Old%20Malton%20and%20Priorpot%20Beck%20in%20Norton.%20The%20Environment%20Agency%20flood%20alert%20added:%20%E2%80%9CWe%20are%20monitoring%20levels%20closely%20and%20have%20staff%20checking%20flood%20defences%20in%20the%20area.%20%20%E2%80%9CContinue%20acting%20on%20your%20flood%20plan.%20%20%E2%80%9CAvoid%20using%20low-lying%20footpaths%20and%20any%20bridges%20near%20local%20watercourses%20and%20do%20not%20attempt%20to%20walk%20or%20drive%20through%20flood%20water.%E2%80%9D) remain in place and have been updated. Areas with flood warnings and flood alerts The flood warning is for the River Derwent at Buttercrambe Mill and areas influenced by rising river levels: - River Derwent at Buttercrambe Mill – Buttercrambe Mill at Buttercrambe Bridge Flood alerts for the following stretches of the River Derwent and areas influenced by rising river levels: - Lower River Derwent – local roads and low-lying land around Stamford Bridge, Pocklington, Wressle, Wilberfoss and Elvington. - Upper River Derwent – the Upper Derwent and Scarborough areas, including land around The Sea Cut at Scalby, Throxenby Beck, Old Malton and Priorpot Beck in Norton. The Environment Agency flood alert added: “We are monitoring levels closely and have staff checking flood defences in the area. “Continue acting on your flood plan. “Avoid using low-lying footpaths and any bridges near local watercourses and do not attempt to walk or drive through flood water.” Comments: Our rules We want our comments to be a lively and valuable part of our community - a place where readers can debate and engage with the most important local issues. The ability to comment on our stories is a privilege, not a right, however, and that privilege may be withdrawn if it is abused or misused. Please report any comments that break our rules. [Read the rules here](/misc/comments)

title: Stormarn: Social-Media-Verbot - Dürfen Schüler bald gar nichts mehr?
